An outdated server encrypted its secrets with RSA, but its primes are both Blum integers. Can you exploit this flaw to recover the original message? 982232773106644640631846852787957454704973029864137825015983928736806263473915582691511126276585378610293435469829935893214767034034157980078615824755459

The flag format is flag{...}
n=8159529248104237976941766690237750750339961231193485855476678150357431190254651304159687505678962162277074927891766502774390998985031636166959674074403501, e=1399183497511128542233887839498651827197922958741278006708992424825673709242537388136793255120351721828643323510902979636586375097709921686345955892623587
The lower 104 bits of p are: 82364847699534885404721451674139966235


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{88b40zyt}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 982232773106644640631846852787957454704973029864137825015983928736806263473915582691511126276585378610293435469829935893214767034034157980078615824755459
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=8159529248104237976941766690237750750339961231193485855476678150357431190254651304159687505678962162277074927891766502774390998985031636166959674074403501, e=1399183497511128542233887839498651827197922958741278006708992424825673709242537388136793255120351721828643323510902979636586375097709921686345955892623587
The lower 104 bits of p are: 82364847699534885404721451674139966235

extra_info: p=85934772258221324774556365680907591431797068049799345251000680540797443586843, q=94950263248339743232955881569388043760814682469280557514575569825494790389207, Ï†(n)=8159529248104237976941766690237750750339961231193485855476678150357431190254470419124180944610954650029824632256573891023871919082266059916593381840427452
